awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The genetics, physiology and evolution of diapause
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Specifically, the fellow will investigate the genetics, physiology, and variation of a biological phenomenon called diapause. Diapause is a period of suspended or arrested development during an insect’s life cycle. The fellow will use the eastern sprice budworm to study diapause. The spruce budworm is a moth species living in the boreal forest across northern America, covering a range from New England to Alaska, and mostly uses diapause to survive harsh winters. The fellow will investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying variation in diapausing moths. This work is important because the spruce budworm is one of the most destructive pest species in North America, and its 35-year cyclical outbreaks have devastating effects on the lumber industry as well as the boreal ecosystem and carbon dynamics. The proposed activity will help us understand how diapause changes across it’s range, which will be crucial for predictive models of budworm range expansion and benefit a robust pest management plan. This in turn will aid the communities depending on the boreal forests. Furthermore, the fellow will engage in several outreach activities to engage high school and college level students with insect research.

Diapause is a fundamental feature in the life cycle of many insects, as it allows insects to survive temporary harsh environmental conditions. Precise timing and regulation of the diapause phenotype can have landscape level consequences, both good (i.e. insects can be important food sources), and bad (i.e. harmful pest species). The fellow will (1) characterize the physiological, transcriptomic and chromatin landscape changes that differentiate diapausing and non-diapausing spruce budworm, (2) determine the genetic basis of this change in the diapause phenotype, and (3), investigate how natural selection acts on the diapause specific regulatory landscape across the range. This study integrates across multiple science disciplines including physiology, functional genomics, genetic mapping and population genetics to study the diapause phenotype. Results from this study will allow us to predict how the diapause phenotype is regulated at different levels, and how natural selection acts on these regulatory mechanisms. The fellow will receive training in integrating physiological and genetic research in an ecological relevant species. Furthermore, the fellow will organize a functional genomics workshop to make advanced molecular techniques available to non-model researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Diapause is a fundamental feature in the life cycle of many insects, as it allows insects to survive temporary harsh environmental conditions. During diapause, insects undergo extensive physiological and transcriptional changes that allow for survival when temperatures are low and food sources are scarce. We investigated the molecular mechanisms that facilitate a shift from diapausing to a diapause-free life cycle. Furthermore, we investigated how local conditions and population history affect the genetic underpinnings of the diapause phenotype.

The eastern spruce budworm is a widespread pest species whose range spans across the boreal forest in northern America, from Alaska to Newfoundland. Across its range, spruce budworm enter diapause as early larvae to survive harsh winters. A non-diapause phenotype exists at low frequency, which appears to have a large genetic component. We compared the genomes from diapausing and the non-diapausing spruce budworm strains, and found very few genetic differences between the strains. However, we did find extensive divergence in gene expression. This suggests that the genetic changes causing a shift from diapause to non-diapause are very minor, but have large-scale consequences for down stream transcription. Furthermore, we found that gene expression diverged halfway during pre-diapause development, indicating the timing of the diapause signal. Genes that diverged between the strains were associated with environmental signal processing and cold-hardiness mechanisms.

Although spruce budworm adults are known to migrate large distances, there is evidence of local adaptation. Using whole genome data, we found that overall population structure in spruce budworm is indeed very weak due to high levels of gene flow, but three sub-populations can be identified, with evidence of changes in natural selection and divergence. Two inversions were identified that increased in frequency further south. We found that the western population diverged earliest from its sister species, and that this population is ancestral to all other spruce budworm populations. This is contrary to the existing hypothesis of a southern refuge during the last glacial maximum, and has changed our understanding on how local adaptation may shape the spruce budworm genome.

During my tenure as a PRFB-fellow, I moved from the University of British Columbia to Clemson University. This opened up the opportunity to provide extensive training in genetics and evolution to high school teachers. I developed several training activities and lectures. Furthermore, I was involved in the mentoring and advising of four graduate students, as well as one undergraduate student.
